awd_titl_txt: Topics in Mathematical Biology and Fluid Mechanics
awd_abstract_narration:
This project focuses on several aspects of mathematical biology and fluid mechanics. Many critical biological phenomena involve fluid-cell interaction or fluid-like behaviors. For example, fertilization of marine animal eggs relies on the transportation of the ambient fluid stream and sardines form large fluid-like swarms to evade predators. The project's principal focus is to develop novel mathematical tools to analyze the various fluid-related or fluid-like effects in these biological phenomena. There are three main topics in this project. The first topic concerns the interaction between the fluid flow and biological phenomena, which is motivated by two experiments in marine animal fertilization and cell embryology. In the first experiment researchers observed optimal fluid speed to maximize the fertilization rate of abalone. The second experiment confirms that the cellular flow helps organ formation at the early stages of the embryos of Drosophila. Fluid mixing effect and fast-spreading effect play important roles in the analysis. These two effects introduce another 'fast diffusion time scale' into the biological system and significantly change the long-time behavior. The principal investigator (PI) plans to develop new mathematical tools that capture the interplay between these fluid phenomena and the biology involved.  The project will provide research training experience for undergraduate students.

A modified hypocoercivity functional, which was applied in the paper by J. Bedrossian and the PI, and detailed spectral analysis, are crucial to derive the 'fast diffusion time scale' in the nonlinear setting. Applying these tools to the biologically relevant models provides deeper understandings of the experiments. The second topic covers the single and multi-species hydrodynamic models of flocking behavior. In these models, the flock of agents converges to a limiting structural state through sharing information among individuals. However, if the agents only share information with their direct neighbors, the flock's limiting behavior is highly nontrivial. The PI plans to develop new tools and bring ideas from spectral graph theory and random graph theory to analyze it. The third topic concerns the growth/blow-up mechanism in fluid mechanics. The PI will study two non-local models related to the generation of small-scale blowup in the fluid motivated by the singular Hou-Luo scenario for the 3D-Euler equation. The tools developed here may turn out to be useful in some biological models.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

inst.inst_name: University of South Carolina at Columbia

por.por_cntn:
Fluid motions are ubiquitous, with many physical processes or biochemical reactions taking place in a fluid environment. Hence, a better understanding of various fluid mechanisms helps one understand interesting phenomena in mathematical biology and fluid mechanics. This project focuses on the small-scale creation, mixing, and enhanced dissipation phenomena accompanying the evolving fluid flow. The PI would like to highlight three aspects of the project.

First, the PI, together with his collaborators, focuses on developing a theoretical toolkit to capture fluid systems' small-scale creation, mixing, and enhanced dissipation phenomena. Consider a cell population in a moving fluid. When the fluid flow is moving fast or exhibits a chaotic pattern, one can observe that the density of the cells, driven by the small vortices in the fluids, forms small-scale structures. This process is sometimes referred to as a mixing phenomenon. When diffusion is involved, mixing induces fast dissipation of the cell density (``enhanced dissipation''). Developing a concrete theoretical description of this picture in various real-life scenarios forms the first part of the project. In various biological settings, the cells tend to move by Levy flights, and hence, the resulting partial differential equation has nonlocal fractional dissipation. In other scenarios, the biological phenomena take place in domains with boundaries. The PI extends the existing analytical tools to these more challenging settings and obtains several sharp results. 

Secondly, the PI and his collaborators confirm that a strong ambient fluid motion can change the qualitative behavior of various interesting biological systems. When considering chemotaxis phenomena in a static environment, the aggregation effect will dominate the overall dynamics if the cell population is sufficiently large. On the partial differential equation model level, one will observe a breakdown (``singularity'') of the model within a finite time. However, with a strong ambient fluid flow, the mixing/enhanced dissipation effect can be so strong that it suppresses the aggregation effect, and the overall evolution of the cells will tend to a stable equilibrium. The PI establishes this observation across various coupled Patlak-Keller-Segel-type systems.

Finally, the PI and his collaborators study the relationship between the rate of various biochemical reactions and the strength of the fluid flow in the environment. As our common sense suggests, if we stir two types of reactants fast enough, the net reaction time can be significantly reduced. The PI quantifies this speed-up with the geometric information of the ambient fluid flow using various tools describing the mixing/enhanced dissipation phenomena. This work can also be generalized to study the relationship between the fertilization success rate of marine animals and the characteristic fluid speed of their surrounding environment.

Other project outcomes involve establishing singularity formation results in fluid models, quantifying the success rate of the stochastic searching process, and characterizing the long-time behavior of flocking/swarming dynamics of birds and fish.

These results are published in mathematic journals focusing on PDE analysis. The PI also gave talks on these outcomes at various conferences and seminars. The PI served as the co-organizer of the conference ``Nonlocal Models: Analysis and Applications'', which took place at the University of South Carolina. The PI also helps guide undergraduate and graduate students in conducting research projects. Some of them continue to pursue research careers in universities.   


Last Modified: 09/13/2024
Modified by: Siming He
